newsitem.title: UK: Sugar freight market sees wave of new enquiry.
newsitem.headline: Sugar freight market sees wave of new enquiry.

text.p: London's sugar freight market saw a spate of fresh enquiry at the start of the week with Cuba and Guatemala prominent as origins for new business, shipbrokers said on Monday.

They also noted a request from Gdynia America Shipping for indications for 100,000 tonnes of bagged sugar to be shipped in 10/14,000 tonne cargoes from Gdansk or Gdynia to Shanghai or Japan. Shipments would start in July and repeat every six weeks.

Cargill was still open with two Thailand enquiries and one for bulk sugar from Rio Haina and quoted one new order for 4,000 tonnes in bags from Puerto Quetzal to Antofagasta and/or Iquique for prompt/May dates.

E D & F Man quoted for 13/750 tonnes min/max bagged sugar from Coatzacoalcos to Chittagong for May 12/20 and was still open with last week's orders from Puerto Quetzal and the Philippines to Algeria and the U.S.
Cuba remained a popular origin as it approached the tail-end of its shipment cycle.
Express Sea Transportation quoted for 25/30,000 tonnes in bulk from Cuba to the Black Sea for June 20/30.

Louis Dreyfus quoted for 24,000 tonnes of bulk sugar from Cuba to the Black Sea with Baltic option for prompt/onwards. Dreyfus was still open with last week's orders for bagged sugar to Tunisia and Maputo.
Czarnikow Rionda quoted for 12/14,000 tonnes of bagged sugar from Mazatkan to the Dakar-Douala range of west Africa for prompt shipment.
Secretan quoted for 5,000 tonnes of pre-slung bagged sugar from Santander to Algeria for May 28/June 3 and 5/7,000 tonnes in bulk from Paranagua to Baltic/Black Sea for prompt dates.
Secretan was also open for 14,000 tonnes of bulk sugar from east coast Mexico to Black Sea/Mediterranean for May 19/23.
NST issued an account order for 10,800 tonnes of bagged sugar from south China to Pakistan with Red Sea option for June 6/10.

Of the day's firmer business, CSR fixed 29,980 tonnes of bulk sugar from Queensland to Kaohsiung for May 25/June 5 and Cargill fixed 14/28,000 tonnes from Puerto Quetzal to US Gulf/Atlantic for May 15/25.
Shipbrokers said Genoc was close to fixing 12/12,500 tonnes of bulk sugar from Thailand to Vladivostok for prompt/10 days notice.
In other news, Pakistan has invited bids, to be opened on May 24, for 50,000 tonnes of white refined crystal sugar to be delivered in two equal shipments by June 30 and July 15.
Stevedores from Brazil's key port of Santos are set to hold talks on Monday with representatives from local steel firm Cosipa to resolve a labor dispute which has already led to two strikes.
Cosipa is expected to reply to the proposal at the meeting to take place at 1700 GMT.
